explanation:
For MISRA C Rule (a function parameter shall not be modified — the pointer itself shall not be changed):
- ARGCHECK (macro): Could expand to code that assigns to/changes the parameter variables or performs a goto/return. Must inspect its expansion to ensure it does not modify the formal parameter 'name' or other parameters.
- LENGTHCHECK (macro): Same reason as ARGCHECK; its expansion may modify parameters or perform control-flow that affects parameter usage.
- OS_ObjectIdGetByName (function prototype): Called with idtype and name; its declaration/signature (const on name?) is needed to confirm it does not accept non-const pointer or otherwise modify the passed-in pointer parameters (especially 'name').
- OS_ObjectIdRelease (function prototype): Called with &token; include its prototype to ensure it does not operate on or modify any of the target function's parameter variables (it should not, but prototype and semantics confirm this).
- OS_object_token_t (type definition): The local variable token is of this type; need its layout (particularly the obj_id member) to confirm that assigning token.obj_id to *object_id modifies the object pointed to (permitted) and not the pointer object_id itself.
- osal_id_t (type definition): The type of *object_id and token.obj_id — needed to confirm the assignment is to the referenced object (allowed) and not a pointer reassignment.
- osal_objtype_t (type definition): Type of idtype parameter — include to confirm it is passed by value and cannot be modified implicitly by called macros/functions.
- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL (macro/enum constant): Value passed to OS_ObjectIdGetByName; include to fully understand the call and ensure no aliasing/side-effect semantics that could modify the caller's parameters.
- OS_SUCCESS (macro/enum constant): Used in the conditional; include to fully interpret control flow (success path) when analyzing whether parameters are modified.
- OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (error code macros): Used by ARGCHECK/LENGTHCHECK; include to inspect macro expansions and see whether they set return_code or modify parameters.

Providing these symbols (macros, prototypes and types) lets the next analyst expand macros and inspect called-function signatures and the token/object_id types to determine definitively whether any of the formal parameters (idtype, name, object_id) are assigned to or otherwise modified (as opposed to the objects they point to).
